etymologies: Middle English: from earlier abackward, from aback

notes.text: In US English, the adverb form is sometimes spelled backwards (the ladder fell backwards), but the adjective is almost always backward (a backward glance). Directional words using the suffix -ward tend to have no s ending in US English, although backwards is more common than afterwards, towards, or forwards. The s ending often (but not always) appears in the phrases backwards and forwards and bending over backwards. In British English, the spelling backwards is more common than backward

definitions: directed behind or to the rear

examples.text: she left the room without a backward glance

definitions: looking toward the past, rather than being progressive; retrograde

examples.text: he said the decision was a backward step

definitions: having made less than normal progress
shortDefinitions: having made less progress than normal

examples.text: a lively child but a bit backward

notes.text: In US English, the adverb form is sometimes spelled backwards (the ladder fell backwards), but the adjective is almost always backward (a backward glance). Directional words using the suffix -ward tend to have no s ending in US English, although backwards is more common than afterwards, towards, or forwards. The s ending often (but not always) appears in the phrases backwards and forwards and bending over backwards. In British English, the spelling backwards is more common than backward

definitions: (of a movement) away from one's front; in the direction of one's back

examples.text: Harry suddenly fell backward into a somersault

definitions: in reverse of the usual direction or order

examples.text: a loving look backward at his early life

definitions: toward or into a worse state

examples.text: a giant step backward for child-centered education
